prj:ScienceGoal.prj:name: Copy of 3C 368
prj:ScienceGoal.prj:note: Detect [NII] 205 um in 3C 368, including on extended scales with the 7m array

prj:TechnicalJustification.prj:justificationText:
We have chosen a correlator setup that maximizes the total continuous bandwidth to ensure we capture all of the velocity components of our source. We set the correlator to operate with 1.875 GHz bandwidth and 0.977 MHz resolution, spectrally averaged by a factor of 16 to cut down on data rates and provide 3.6 km/s resolution.
Our representative baseband is centered on our line, straddled by a base band on either side and a final baseband on either the red or blue side. This provides ~3500 km/s of continuous spectral coverage, covering either (-1311 to +2185 km/s) or (-2185 to +1311 km/s).

We request a compact configuration with complementary ACA observations. Given our requested sensitivities, the [NII] line should be detectable at resolutions ~2.3'' from the ACA. The possibility of highly extended structure on the scale of the (~6'') lobes seen at 1.3 mm continuum further compels us to use the ACA for its maximum recoverable scale.

Our anticipated [NII] 205um line flux is based on our known [CII] line flux. Based on a set of ~250 local sources in the Great Observatories All-sky LIRG Survey (GOALS) in which both [CII] and [NII] 205 were detected, we assume a minimum [NII]/[CII] ratio of 0.04. This cut-off encompasses ~95% of the GOALS sample. In this source, previous observations suggest there may be emission on extended scales, and so we are particularly interested in ACA 7m array observations. At this redshift (1''=8.338 kpc) it is likely the bulk of the star formation will be concentrated within one beam of the ACA (~20 kpc), so we do not assume any beam dilution surface brightness dimming.
([CII] line flux) x (0.04) = anticipated [NII] line flux per beam
We assume our [NII] line width will be similar to our detected [CII] line, ~500 km/s. Since this is a detection experiment and we don't need detailed line velocity profiles, we will use the FWHM width for our detection. We generally set requested sensitivites to achieve a S/N of 10.

We have chosen a correlator setup that maximizes the total continuous bandwidth to ensure we capture all of the velocity components of our source. We set the correlator to operate with 1.875 GHz bandwidth and 0.977 MHz resolution, spectrally averaged by a factor of 16 to cut down on data rates and provide 3.6 km/s resolution.
Our representative baseband is centered on our line, straddled by a base band on either side and a final baseband on either the red or blue side. This provides ~3500 km/s of continuous spectral coverage, covering either (-1311 to +2185 km/s) or (-2185 to +1311 km/s).

We request a compact configuration to minimize surface brightness dimming from resolution. Given our requested sensitivities, the [NII] line should be detectable at resolutions ~0.5'', although coarser resolution would be equally acceptable. The possibility of extended structure in the form of jets sets our largest angular scale to ~3''.

Our anticipated [NII] 205um line flux is based on our known [CII] line flux. Based on a set of ~250 local sources in the Great Observatories All-sky LIRG Survey (GOALS) in which both [CII] and [NII] 205 were detected, we assume a minimum [NII]/[CII] ratio of 0.04. This cut-off encompasses ~95% of the GOALS sample. Our [CII] observations are spatially unresolved. In this QSO source we expect star formation to be confined to <1 kpc, much smaller than the 0.5'' beam. Some minor amount of emission, however, may be associated with extended jets. We therefore assume a `beam dilution' factor ~0.5 (roughly half of the anticipated total line flux will fall into a single beam).
([CII] line flux) x (0.04) x (beam dilution) = anticipated [NII] line flux per beam
We assume our [NII] line width will be similar to our detected [CII] line, ~500 km/s. Since this is a detection experiment and we don't need detailed line velocity profiles, we will use the FWHM width for our detection. We generally set requested sensitivites to achieve a S/N of 10.

We have chosen a correlator setup that maximizes the total continuous bandwidth to ensure we capture all of the velocity components of our source. We set the correlator to operate with 1.875 GHz bandwidth and 0.977 MHz resolution, spectrally averaged by a factor of 16 to cut down on data rates and provide 3.6 km/s resolution.
Our representative baseband is centered on our line, straddled by a base band on either side and a final baseband on either the red or blue side. This provides ~3500 km/s of continuous spectral coverage, covering either (-1311 to +2185 km/s) or (-2185 to +1311 km/s).

We request a compact configuration to minimize surface brightness dimming from resolution. Given our requested sensitivities, the [NII] line should be detectable at resolutions ~0.5'', although coarser resolution would be equally acceptable. The possibility of extended structure in the sets our largest angular scale to ~3''.

Our anticipated [NII] 205um line flux is based on our known [CII] line flux. Based on a set of ~250 local sources in the Great Observatories All-sky LIRG Survey (GOALS) in which both [CII] and [NII] 205 were detected, we assume a minimum [NII]/[CII] ratio of 0.04. This cut-off encompasses ~95% of the GOALS sample. Our [CII] observations are spatially unresolved. In SMGs optical detections suggest emission over scales ~1'', while the ALMA band 9 compact configuration beam is ~0.5''. We therefore assume a `beam dilution' surface brightness factor ~0.25 (roughly one quarter of the anticipated total line flux will fall into a single beam).
([CII] line flux) x (0.04) x (beam dilution) = anticipated [NII] line flux per beam
We assume our [NII] line width will be similar to our detected [CII] line, ~500 km/s. Since this is a detection experiment and we don't need detailed line velocity profiles, we will use the FWHM width for our detection. We generally set requested sensitivites to achieve a S/N of 10.

We set the correlator to operate with 1.875 GHz bandwidth and 0.977 MHz resolution, spectrally averaged by a factor of 16 to cut down on data rates and provide 3.6 km/s resolution.
Our representative baseband is centered on our line, straddled by a base band on either side and a final baseband on either the red or blue side. This provides ~3500 km/s of continuous spectral coverage, covering either (-1311 to +2185 km/s) or (-2185 to +1311 km/s).

We request a compact configuration to minimize surface brightness dimming from resolution. Given our requested sensitivities, the [NII] line should be detectable at resolutions ~0.5'', although coarser resolution would be equally acceptable. The possibility of extended structure in the sets our largest angular scale to ~3''.

Our anticipated [NII] 205um line flux is based on our known [CII] line flux. Based on a set of ~250 local sources in the Great Observatories All-sky LIRG Survey (GOALS) in which both [CII] and [NII] 205 were detected, we assume a minimum [NII]/[CII] ratio of 0.04. This cut-off encompasses ~95% of the GOALS sample. Our [CII] observations are spatially unresolved. In SMGs optical detections suggest emission over scales ~1'', while the ALMA band 9 compact configuration beam is ~0.5''. We therefore assume a `beam dilution' surface brightness factor ~0.25 (roughly one quarter of the anticipated total line flux will fall into a single beam).
([CII] line flux) x (0.04) x (beam dilution) = anticipated [NII] line flux per beam
We assume our [NII] line width will be similar to our detected [CII] line, ~500 km/s. Since this is a detection experiment and we don't need detailed line velocity profiles, we will use the FWHM width for our detection. We generally set requested sensitivites to achieve a S/N of 10.

We have chosen a correlator setup that maximizes the total continuous bandwidth to ensure we capture all of the velocity components of our source. We set the correlator to operate with 1.875 GHz bandwidth and 0.977 MHz resolution, spectrally averaged by a factor of 16 to cut down on data rates and provide 3.6 km/s resolution.
Our representative baseband is centered on our line, straddled by a base band on either side and a final baseband on either the red or blue side. This provides ~3500 km/s of continuous spectral coverage, covering either (-1311 to +2185 km/s) or (-2185 to +1311 km/s).

We request a compact configuration to minimize surface brightness dimming from resolution. Given our requested sensitivities, the [NII] line should be detectable at resolutions ~0.5'', although coarser resolution would be equally acceptable. The possibility of extended structure in the form of jets sets our largest angular scale to ~3''.

Our anticipated [NII] 205um line flux is based on our known [CII] line flux. Based on a set of ~250 local sources in the Great Observatories All-sky LIRG Survey (GOALS) in which both [CII] and [NII] 205 were detected, we assume a minimum [NII]/[CII] ratio of 0.04. This cut-off encompasses ~95% of the GOALS sample. Our [CII] observations are spatially unresolved. In this QSO source we expect star formation to be confined to <1 kpc, much smaller than the 0.5'' beam. Some minor amount of emission, however, may be associated with extended jets. We therefore assume a `beam dilution' factor ~0.5 (roughly half of the anticipated total line flux will fall into a single beam).
([CII] line flux) x (0.04) x (beam dilution) = anticipated [NII] line flux per beam
We assume our [NII] line width will be similar to our detected [CII] line, ~500 km/s. Since this is a detection experiment and we don't need detailed line velocity profiles, we will use the FWHM width for our detection. We generally set requested sensitivites to achieve a S/N of 10.
Due to the finite calibration time and overheads associated with each observation, we set a minimum onsource time of 10 minutes. For this, relatively bright, source that results in a satisfactory S/N ~ 14.

prp:ObsProposal.prp:abstract: We propose to use ALMA band 9 to observe the [NII]205 um transition in 5 galaxies at z=1.2 from which we have detected emission in the [CII]158 um line. The [CII] transition is emitted by molecular gas ionized and heated by stellar UV radiation, and in the ALMA era promises to be a crucial workhorse in high redshift surveys. The [NII]205 um line is a sensitive tracer of ionized gas, and complements the [CII] line as a star formation diagnostic. We will use the [NII] line to measure the fraction of the ISM in these galaxies that has been ionized by stellar radiation, and use this to determine the intensity of the starburst. We will also use the [NII] line, compared with the continuum emission, to trace the hardness of the UV field, thereby determining the spectral type of the most massive stars or inferring the presence of an AGN. Finally, we will use the [NII]/[CII] ratio to determine how much of the measured [CII] arises from ionized gas rather than PDRs. These observations will be an essential reference for future ALMA high-z [CII] studies. This project is a resubmission of a highly ranked cycle 1 project (carried over to cycle 2) with updated source list.
prp:ObsProposal.prp:relatedProposals: 2015.1.00157.S PI Carl Ferkinhoff - a survey of similar [CII] z=1-2 sources in CO 2015.1.01033.S PI Thomas Nikola - a FIR line census of SMM J03
prp:ObsProposal.prp:previousProposals: 2012.1.00426.S PI Steve Hailey-Dunsheth - a highly ranked but not completed survey of [NII] in z=1-2 [CII] emitters
prp:ObsProposal.prp:scientificCategoryString: Cosmology and the High Redshift Universe

prp:PrincipalInvestigator.prp:organisation: Nucleo de Astronomia, Universidad Diego Portales

Center for Radiophysics and Space Research, Cornell University
